f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (17:00): hmm. I think I need to write a test to see which one really is faster.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:00): var t=new Date();for(var i=0;i<100000;++i)var z=[i,i,i,i,i,i];alert(new Date()-t)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:01): var t=new Date();for(var i=0;i<100000;++i)var z=new Array(i,i,i,i,i,i);alert(new Date()-t)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:01): In Firefox 3, the former takes 270ms, the latter takes 130ms
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:01): but unless you're initialising a hundred thousand arrays you're not going to notice the difference so you should use [...] because it's so much prettier
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:02): The same code in Opera 9.5 is the other way around, taking 430ms and 540ms
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:04): In Safari 3.0 it's 160ms/130ms
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:06): In IE6 it's roughly 950ms for both
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (17:06): If you really care about performance, nobody uses Opera so you should use new Array()
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (17:06): wonders if ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c forgot about IE
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (17:07): IE7 is faster with [] than new Array
